unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Making Decisions from Output | 1 of 2
question_text:
A veterinarian decided to study the weights (kg) of Siberian and Alaskan huskies.
The veterinarian weighted $13$ randomly selected Siberian huskies and $12$ randomly selected Alaskan huskies. A two-sample $t$-test was performed with the results below (two-sided).
Two-Sample $t$ for Siberian Husky vs. Alaskan Husky:
N Mean StDev SE Mean
Siberian Husky 13 18.66 3.89 1.1
Alaskan Husky 12 23.27 2.47 0.71


$\text{Difference }= \mu \text{(Siberian husky)}-\mu \text{(Alaskan husky)}$
Estimate for difference: $-4.61$
$95\%$ confidence interval for difference: $(-7.3, -1.91)$
$\text{T-test of Difference }= 0$
$\text{T-value }= -3.56$
$\text{P-value }= 0.002$
$\text{DF }= 20$
What practical conclusions can be made based on these results?

choices.text: There is no evidence of a difference in weights between the different husky breeds at any of the common alpha levels.
There is evidence of a difference in weights at the $10\%$ level, but not at the $1\%$ or $5\%$ alpha levels.
There is evidence of a difference in weights at the $5\%$ and $10\%$ levels, but not at the $1\%$ level.
There is evidence of a difference in weights at the $1\%$, $5\%$, and $10\%$ alpha levels.
There is evidence Alaskan huskies weigh more than Siberian huskies at the $1\%, 5\%$, and $10\%$ alpha levels.
